title: 113_hr1929
content: The Act is titled the "Enhancing Employment and Training Through Education Act of 2013." It includes pilot projects to reduce dependency and increase work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. Section 17 of the Food and Nutrition Act of 2008 is amended to include pilot projects aimed at reducing dependency and increasing work effort in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program. The projects will focus on identifying best practices for employment and training programs to help participants secure unsubsidized employment, increase earned income, and reduce reliance on public assistance. Selection criteria for the pilot projects will be based on established criteria by the Secretary. The pilot projects under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program aim to reduce dependency and increase work effort by enhancing existing employment and training programs, collaborating with job training programs, and ensuring replicability in other states. The pilot projects under the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program aim to enhance existing employment and training programs by collaborating with job training programs, ensuring replicability in other states, and targeting a variety of work registrants. The pilot projects aim to enhance existing employment and training programs by collaborating with job training programs and targeting individuals with low skills or limited work experience from a range of existing programs. This includes section 20 workfare, skills development, post-employment support services, and education leading to recognized credentials. The pilot projects aim to enhance employment and training programs by collaborating with job training programs and targeting individuals with low skills or limited work experience. The projects include post-employment support services, education leading to recognized credentials, and evaluation to measure impact. Participants are located in various geographic areas and may be exempt or non-exempt under specific sections. The Secretary will conduct an independent evaluation of pilot projects to measure their impact on participants' ability to find and retain employment leading to increased household income and reduced dependency. A report detailing the evaluation results must be submitted to Congress by September 30, 2017. The Secretary will submit a report to Congress by September 30, 2017, detailing the results of pilot projects, including their impact on employment, income, and public benefit receipt of work registrants, along with costs, dissemination of findings, and steps for incorporating project components. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects that aim to increase employment and earnings. The funds will be used for projects that comply with specific guidelines. The Secretary will allocate $10,000,000 annually from 2014 to 2016 for pilot projects that comply with specific guidelines. The funds will be used for project costs, administration, data provision, and evaluation expenses. Non-Federal funds cannot be replaced by the funds provided. The allocated funds under this subsection cannot replace non-Federal funds for existing employment and training activities.
